PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Estudo do Binфmio Mгe-Filho: uma necessidade imperada para atingir os objetivos do Desenvolvimento do Milкnio
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Em 2010, a FSP/USP, sob os auspнcios da FAPESP (Proc. 09/53253-8), deu inicio a realizaзгo desta investigaзгo, que se propunha analisar dados relativos а mulher do momento em que engravida e durante a sua gestaзгo atй o parto e puerpйrio imediato, englobando tambйm um estudo relativo ao produto desta gestaзгo. Os objetivos foram: GERAL - Estudar o binфmio mгe-filho por meio de prontuбrios/entrevistas com puйrperas internadas em maternidades. ESPECНFICOS - Avaliar a morbidade materna por causas obstйtricas (direta e indiretas) e outras causas (naturais e externas), por meio de doenзas/agravos ocorridos ou existentes durante a gravidez; Identificar variбveis que podem influir na saъde das puйrperas, entre as quais, idade, com кnfase especial nas adolescentes, assistкncia prй-natal, nъmero de gestaзхes e partos anteriores, escolaridade, condiзгo marital; calcular a razгo de mortalidade materna para as maternidades estudadas; mensurar os produtos da gestaзгo dessas mulheres segundo o tipo: nascido vivo, nascido morto e aborto, estudando algumas de suas caracterнsticas, como Peso e Apgar dos recйm-nascidos vivos e a presenзa de anomalias congкnitas e outras patologias que possam afetб-los.
A populaзгo de estudo foi de mulheres internadas em hospitais selecionados e que tiveram como desfecho de suas gravidezes, parto ou aborto (incluindo gravidez ectуpica e mola hidatiforme), em perнodo determinado.
A metodologia de trabalho consistiu em entrevistas com puйrperas e consultas a dados do prontuбrio, livro da sala de parto e outros registros hospitalares, bem como, sempre que possнvel, da carteira da gestante.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Land transport injuries among emergency department visits in the state of Sгo Paulo, in 2005.

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Revista de Saъde Pъblica / Journal of Public Health

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Maria Helena Prado de Mello Jorge
AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: MELLO JORGE, Maria Helena Prado de;Jorge, Maria Helena Prado de Mello;MELLO JORGE, MARIA HELENA PRADO;JORGE, M. HELENA P. DE MELLO;MELLO-JORGE, MARIA HELENA PRADO DE

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: OBJECTIVE: To analyze the characteristics of visits resulting from land transport injuries. METHODS: A total of 5,934 visits in four hospital emergency departments (ED) were analyzed, in the state of Sгo Paulo, in 2005. A questionnaire based on the following three models was used to collect data: World Health Organization (WHO), Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and Pan American Health Organization (PAHO). Variables analyzed were as follows: type of road user (vehicle occupant, pedestrian, motorcyclist, and cyclist), sex, age group, and type of injury suffered. Logistic regression analysis was employed to test associations between variables. Odds ratios with their respective 95% confidence intervals were calculated. RESULTS: The majority of victims were males (74.2%) in the 20-to-29-year age group (35.0%). Vulnerable road users totaled 72.4% of all cases (29.8% were motorcyclists, 24.1% pedestrians, and 18.5% cyclists). Victims aged between zero and 14 years who had suffered injuries were mostly pedestrians and cyclists; motorcyclists predominated among those aged between 15 and 39 years; and pedestrians among those aged over 50 years. About half of the cases suffered minor injuries (strains, dislocations, contusions and cuts), while the other half was comprised by fractures, traumatic brain injuries and internal injuries. Extremities were the most affected body parts, particularly among motorcyclists. The majority of victims were discharged at triage (87.6%). Compared to women, men were 1.5 times more likely to be admitted or transferred, or to die. Pedestrians, vehicle occupants and motorcyclists were, respectively, 2.7, 2.4 and 1.9 times more likely to be admitted or transferred, or to die than cyclists. CONCLUSIONS: Measures aimed to protect vulnerable road users should be among the priorities to reduce land transport-related injuries.
